Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Larimer County Commissioners will soon decide whether to spend over $100 million dollars, without the approval of taxpayers, to double the size of the Larimer County Jail. Though citizens have spoken clearly by twice rejecting ballot initiatives for a bigger jail, commissioners plan to bypass a community vote and fund an expansion through controversial Certificates of Participation.

Contact the commissioners today. Urge them to reject the expensive and unnecessary jail expansion.

While the ACLU supports renovations that would improve jail conditions, the proposed expansion goes far beyond refurbishmentâ€”unnecessarily adding 500 new beds at a time when new state laws aimed at de-carceration (including HB 19-1225) are still taking effect and there is growing recognition across the nation that incarceration is harmful to communities.

With a bigger jail, there will be no incentive to consciously limit jail space to those who pose a danger to the public. One thing is clear: If they build it, they will fill it. Shockingly, if the 500 additional beds were filled, Larimer County would spend nearly $60,000 each day in housing costs on top of the $100 million spent for construction.

Before footing such an expensive bill, Larimer County should critically examine who it is incarcerating and why. Close to 35 percent of the jail population is homeless and over 60 percent of the jail population has not been found guilty, meaning they are innocent in the eyes of the law and remain in custody simply because they cannot afford to post bail while they await trial.

There are faster, more cost-effective ways to manage the jail population, such as reducing reliance on cash bail to ensure more defendants are released pretrial, de-criminalizing homelessness, investing in permanent supportive housing, and enhancing community-based services.

Contact your county commissioners. Let them know that Larimer County does not need a bigger jail.

Make your voice heard by attending the vote and signing-up for public comment to Stop Larimer County Jail Expansion:
